Description: Fragment from a limestone figure of the king Ramses I, only part of the back-pillar now remaining. What survives of the back-pillar records part of the titulary of the king, known as the Horus name, in a single column of text. The outer edges of the back-pillar are preserved on the right side, and on the left side are the smoothed edges of the stone between the back-pillar and partial outline of what was likely a figure. The corners at the top of the back-pillar have been damaged, and the obverse of the stone figure is now lost. There are small chips to the stone around the inscribed area, however the text is still discernible.
Curator's comments: The fragment is recorded as being found within the Deir el-Bahri area of Thebes, however the precise findspot is uncertain. A range of other votive statue fragments from the later phases of the New Kingdom were also found within the temple site. As with most royal titulary, what may have followed in the now lost inscription would have included further royal names and titles. Due to the fragmentary nature of the figure, it’s not possible to tell what the original statue type may have been.
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Ramses I
